FACILITY DESCRIBTION:



The Vallecitos Water District (VWD) uses chlorine at the Meadowlark Water Reclamation Facility for water treatment, for bacterial and viral destruction and odor control, and to control slime and algae growth. Multiple feed points are provided to give flexibility in achieving disinfection goals. Disinfection is achieved by withdrawing gaseous chlorine for 1-ton cylinders, and feeding through chlorinators (with integral vacuum regulators), an automatic switch over assembly, rotameters, and injectors.



Normally, three cylinders resting on the scale feed the system through one of two pipe manifolds. Three other cylinders are on standby and one cylinder is available as a reserve. An underhung bridge crane is used for handling cylinders. 



The feed equipment consist of chlorinators with integral vacuum regulators to meter the gas under vacuum and injectors to create the vacuum and mix the gas with water for transport and application. The system is under vacuum from the injectors to the vacuum regulator at each 1-ton cylinder. From the vacuum regulator to the 1-ton cylinder, the system is pressurized. Pressurized chlorine piping is minimal.



Two chlorine leak detectors are provided in the chlorine storage room and one in the chlorination room. In addition to the alarm annunciation and rotating beacons, warning lights are installed near each entry to the chlorination room and chlorine storage room. Also, an automated alarm system and auto-dialing equipment is installed to notify VWD personnel in the event of a leak.



CHEMICALS SUBJECT TO EPA'S ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM:



VWD uses chlorine at the Meadowlark Water Reclamation Facility in quantities large enough to trigger the Accidental Release Prevention Program. Chlorine is transported to the facility by truck, stored on-site in one-ton cylinders, and used for water disinfection. Typically three 1-ton chlorine cylinders are in use, three are in standby mode and one spare 1-ton

cylinder are stored at the facility.



PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM:



The VWD Meadowlark Water Reclamation Facility is subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations for all equipment and operations associated with chlorine storage and disinfection systems. VWD's PSM programs include the following to minimize the potential for an accidental release:

- Review of the design of all equipment and controls for the chlorine system to ensure they are properly designed and installed.

- Update standard operating procedures to include specific information on safety procedures. All procedures must be reviewed and certified annually.

- Initial safety training and 3-year refresher training for all operators and maintenance staff.

- Procedures to ensure that all contractors receive the same safety training that VWD provides its own employees

- Regular inspection of all equipment, monitoring systems and controls, including documentation of all inspections.

- Prompt corrective action for any non-conforming items identified by the regular inspections.

- Safety reviews conconducted prior to system startup, if any equipment or operations are modified.

- Investigation of any incidents that have the potential to have caused chlorine releases.

- Periodic evaluation of the safety records of all outside contractors who work on the RMP-regulated system.

- Development of an effective emergency response program.

- Implementation of an employee participation program to ensure that all plant-wide staff are aware of the PSM/RMP program, and are actively consulted regarding safety issues.

-Independent audits of the entire PSM/RMP program every three years.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:



The VWD Meadowlark Water Reclamation Facility has not had any releases during the past five years that resulted in any injuries, off-site evacuations, or property damage.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES:



VWD uses its Emergency Response Plan to provide s

tep-by-step procedures for emergency response in the unlikely event of an accidental release. The key elements of the emergency prepareness program are as follows:

- All plant staff are trained in the specific elements of the program.

- A team of safety professionals, supervisors and operators are trained, certified and equipped for hazardous materials (Hazmat) emergency operations to repair accidental releases.

- The plant uses a combination of audible alarms and a plant loudspeaker system to alert staff of a potential accident and to conduct in-plant communication.

- In the event of a large chlorine release, the facility would automatically contact a telephone call-down list that includes City of Carlsbad Fire Department, the County of San Diego's Hazmat Response Team and the San Diego County Sheriff's Department. In addition to assisting with the accidental release these agencies will assist in notifying the public and evacuation procedures if needed.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVEMENT SAFETY:



VWD is planning the installation of on-site storage of Sodium Hypochlorite to eliminate the chlorine gas process, which will increase safety at the plant and remove the facility from the RMP.
